normalised: Understanding Time References in News Reports: A Guide

unnormalised: News reports often contain various time references, and understanding them is crucial for interpreting the information accurately. These references can appear in different formats, some straightforward and others less so. This guide aims to clarify some common time-related conventions used in Indian English news. For example, a report might mention "yesterday," which, depending on the publication date, needs context. Similarly, specific dates like "15/08/1947" pinpoint historical moments, while future events are often indicated with dates like "01/01/2025."

Similarly, specific dates like "fifteenth august one thousand nine hundred and forty seven" pinpoint historical moments, while future events are often indicated with dates like "first january two thousand and twenty five."

unnormalised: One frequent element is the inclusion of specific times alongside dates. You might see something like "The incident occurred at 3:45 PM IST on 26/07/2024." IST, or Indian Standard Time, is the standard time zone observed throughout India. News sources may also refer to "last week" or "early this month," which requires considering the publication date to determine the specific timeframe. Pay close attention to whether the report uses a 12-hour (AM/PM) or 24-hour clock, as both are common. So, 6:00 PM and 18:00 both refer to the same time.
normalised: One frequent element is the inclusion of specific times alongside dates. You might see something like "The incident occurred at three forty five P-M I-S-T on twenty sixth july two thousand and twenty four." I-S-T, or Indian Standard Time, is the standard time zone observed throughout India. News sources may also refer to "last week" or "early this month," which requires considering the publication date to determine the specific timeframe. Pay close attention to whether the report uses a twelve-hour (A-M slash P-M) or twenty-four-hour clock, as both are common. So, six P-M and eighteen zero zero both refer to the same time.

unnormalised: Abbreviations also play a role. "ET," meaning Eastern Time, may appear when referencing events in the US. In historical pieces, you might encounter references to eras such as "the 1990s." Furthermore, understanding the significance of public holidays is vital. A statement like "offices will remain closed on 2nd Oct" implicitly refers to Gandhi Jayanti, a nationally observed holiday. Be wary of "TBA" (To Be Announced) or "TBD" (To Be Determined) which means time and date is not yet decided.

unnormalised: Seasonal references are also prevalent, particularly in India. For instance, mentions of "the monsoon season" provide a timeframe, albeit a broad one, for certain events. Similarly, references to festivals like "Diwali, falling on 04/11/2024," can provide a cultural context for timing. News related to agriculture will frequently use months like "Rabi crop sowing starting from Nov."

unnormalised: By carefully analyzing these time-related elements, readers can effectively decode the information presented in news reports. Remember to consider the context, the specific formats used, and any cultural references embedded within the text to gain a comprehensive understanding of the timeline of events. Also understand time-sensitive wording like, "till 5 PM today," and "within 24 hrs," etc.
